& 𝘈 𝘓𝘦𝘵𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘍𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘠𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘛𝘦𝘢𝘤𝘩𝘦𝘳 💌
•TPT & Blog 👩🏻‍💻
•2nd grade has my heart 💗
•Love to travel! ✈️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers in Palm Desert, California. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
You know those times when you’re busy having fun so you forget to take pictures? 📸 

My family went on a spur-of-the-moment trip to Palm Springs this past weekend 🌴☀️ As we were just about to head home, we passed by this sign. 

I thought to myself…oops, I have not taken a single photo on this entire trip! So I told my girls (who were still practically dripping from the pool), “Quick, go stand in front of that sign!” so we’d have at least one picture from our little getaway 😆 

How was your weekend?? Whether you’re still on break or your school year has started back up again, I hope you got to squeeze in a bit of time for fun! 💛 #teachertraveltuesday

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 23, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
I received an email recently from a teacher who had a question about a custom order. This quote from Emilie Buchwald was under her email signature.

I thought, what a great message to have automated on your work emails (all those ones you send to parents/families of your students). A simple yet powerful reminder to help encourage reading together at home! 📚💗 

Do you include a quote with your automated signature for work emails? Would love to hear what yours says, feel free to share with other teachers in the comments below! 💞

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 22, 2021.

node.text:
“Guess who” loves to play games in the classroom? Pretty much every kid I’ve ever known! 

Guess Who is a fun, engaging way to practice addition facts and math vocabulary. There’s a whole lot of rigor and higher level thinking going on too (which the kids don’t even realize, because they just get so into the game)! It works great as a math center and/or as a choice for your early finishers. 

I’ve got a ton of games for all kinds of other math skills too, which you can check out at bit.ly/guesswhomathgames or at the link in my profile 💙

Photo shared by Life Between Summers on August 19, 2021 tagging @novel_effect. May be an image of 1 person and book.

node.text:
A brand new, exciting way to share “A Letter From Your Teacher” with your students! If you’ve never heard of Novel Effect, it’s a free app that brings an extra element of magic to your read alouds ✨

All you need is your own copy of the book in your hands (and an iPhone or iPad nearby). As the app “hears” you reading out loud, it gives accompanying sound effects and music to make the story come even more alive! 

For example, there’s the part in the book with the illustration of the little girl up to bat in baseball ⚾️ After you read aloud the line, “I cannot wait to get to know you, and all the things that make you YOU,” kids will hear the sound of a baseball being hit and the crowd going wild. SO COOL! I just tried it out yesterday with my own kids at home, and they enjoyed it sooo much! 💕

Not only is this fun for read alouds, but I think it would also make for a super engaging literacy center! 💡 As kids read stories aloud, they get to hear sound effects and music to accompany their own voice as they read. How motivating is that?? 

The app includes a ton of free soundscapes for classic children’s books that you probably already have in your classroom library. There’s also an option to upgrade for premium unlimited access, where you get all of their ebooks too (use the code TEACH30 for 30% off through 8/31)!

I’ve shared the link to this in my profile and stories (just download the Novel Effect app first, and then the link will take you right to my book). 

And if you want to hop over to @novel_effect here on IG, they’re also giving away a free autographed hardcover copy of the book this week! 👏🏼

Have you used Novel Effect before, or is this your first time hearing about it?? Let me know what you think! 🥰

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers in Peaks Island. May be an image of 3 people, child and outdoors.

node.text:
Still savoring some summertime on this #teachertraveltuesday! 💙 

We were walking to a bike rental shop so we could explore this island off the coast of Maine, but on our way we saw a golf cart place instead. I love a good bike ride, but the lazy side of me does have to say this was definitely the way to go! 😆 

What’s your favorite way to get around when seeing someplace new? Leave an emoji below! 🚶🏻‍♀️🚲🚙🛥

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
My author visits are in full swing this month! 👏🏼 To say I enjoy visiting with classes is an understatement…I LOVE getting to talk with kids all about the writing/publishing process for “Our Class is a Family” and “A Letter From Your Teacher” 📚 

The positive feedback from teachers & library media specialists has meant everything to me, but my favorite responses are the ones that come from kids 💓 After one past visit, the teacher shared with me that one of her sweet 2nd graders told her she was starting to work on her own manuscript (a term I had taught the class) 😍

For me, that’s what it’s all about right there 🥰 Getting kids excited about building class community, but also excited about writing…and maybe even inspiring some who might want to write their own book one day! ✏️

I am booked through the next couple of months, but still have some dates open in late October and early November. If you’d like a virtual visit for your class, grade level, or school, there’s a link in my profile or you can go to bit.ly/authorvisitswithshannonolsen 💛 

Are you planning on having any guests or speakers visit with your class this year, whether virtually or in person?? 😊

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 15, 2021.

node.text:
When it comes to any kind of organization bins (book bins, storage bins, etc.) the high quality ones from @lakeshorelearning have always been my go-to! #ad 

Not only do I love all the bright color options 🌈 but more importantly, those babies are durable! Their bins have withstood years in my classroom, and that’s with lots of hands-on use. The ones pictured here are the Neon Help Yourself Book Bins and the Neon Heavy-Duty Storage Boxes. 

I’ve also shared my favorite top 5 Lakeshore Learning items for classroom organization in a new blog post. The link is in my profile and stories 💕

Lakeshore is having their biggest sale of the year right now too! If you have your eye on anything that’s not already discounted though, make sure to use my coupon code (6392) for 20% off any single non-sale item 😊

Coupon code valid ‪through 9/12/2021 for one-time use in stores or online. Limit one coupon per customer. Not valid on items with shipping restrictions. Other exclusions may apply. Visit bit.ly/3bbUXIj  for details #learnwithlakeshore #sponsored‬

node.text:
On Fridays, I usually like to share a post from someone in the teaching community for #teacherfollowfriday 👩🏻‍🏫💕 But today, I just have to show some love for a mom who is amazingly thoughtful and SO SUPPORTIVE of her kids’ teachers! 💗

@kristensellentin, you have outdone yourself with this back to school gift basket. And your book display too!! 😍 Not only is it beautiful, but you’re helping to foster a love of reading at home for your kids. Teachers appreciate parents like you! 🥰

Photo shared by Life Between Summers on August 12, 2021 tagging @officialcricut. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Cricut beginner here! 🙋🏻‍♀️ #ad I’ll be completely honest, I put off learning how to use a Cricut for the longest time…I’m not the quickest learner when it comes to machines, and I always thought it would take me forever to watch tutorials and figure it out. I was also a little intimidated by all of the amazing projects I’ve seen teachers create.
 
Well, now I feel absolutely ridiculous for thinking that way 🙈 You guys…it was SO EASY! I used the Cricut Maker 3, and I decided to dip my toes in the water with something simple. I made some sticker letters for a “Penmanship Prize” that can be used to recognize a student who has been putting extra effort into having neat handwriting. That student gets to use/keep the special pens on their desk all week.  
 
Using Cricut Design Space and Cricut fonts, it was seriously as easy as typing the text and pressing a couple of buttons. I’ve heard that you need a mat for some of the original @officialcricut models, but with the Maker 3 you don’t need one at all! The ease was very similar to just using a regular printer. If I can do it, anyone can do it 😆
 
In case you don’t want to wait as long as I did to hop on the Cricut train (I am now regretting all the time I’ve spent hand cutting bulletin board letters over the years) 🤦🏻‍♀️ I’ve shared an affiliate link for this in my profile and stories!
 
#cricutmade

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 12, 2021.
Photo by Life Between Summers in Central Park, New York. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
“I’ll be there for you…” 🎶 Who loves Friends?? 💜 (or my favorite sort-of-similar show, How I Met Your Mother)? 💛 

We stopped in NYC on our recent trip to the east coast, and took this picture at what we were told was the fountain from the opening credits of Friends. But I came to find out later that it was actually filmed at a studio in Burbank (in my home state of CA) 🤷🏻‍♀️😂 Guess we didn’t need to travel that far! 

Either way, my family and I enjoyed Central Park (no fountain-swimming took place, btw) 😉 #teachertraveltuesday

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Life Between Summers on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text.

node.text:
Back to school plans are often jam-packed with team-building activities and ice breakers…which is wonderful! 💛 But class community is also built in those seemingly small interactions with “your people.” Examples:
 
-When kids tell you something about their life outside of school, remembering to ask about it again later (“How was your soccer game?”)

-Giving a student a special nickname (making sure it’s something they like being called, of course). I had a student named Claire who always gave me the biggest grin when I called her Claire Bear.

-If you can’t hug/high-5 etc. right now due to COVID restrictions, coming up with contactless ways to greet each other. An “air” fist-bump, making a heart shape with your hands, etc.
 
These are the simple types of things that teachers do all the time, of course…I’ve always just found it reassuring to remember that building community doesn’t always have to be a grandiose lesson plan! It’s the little everyday things that make kids feel the biggest connection to you 💗
